message: Well.
Ill put my hand up and say yes!
I'm in my fresher year at uni
@pg interesting to know! Sort of off-topic here, have any acceptance/rejection emails been sent out so far?
There are always a significant number.  We often see ones we think would succeed.  But we are very wary of funding HS students.  We don't want to mess up people's lives.
@pg ok, thanks!
@simonify No, we send all the emails at once.
It's 6:30 in the evening here in the UK, the suspense is killing me ha. Probably going to go out and escape reality for a few hours.
I doubt I got in though
Young Combinator
@pg you say you're worried about messing up people's lives, what aspects in specific worry you?
@LordJawsh I'm guessing it would be pulling a kid out of high school, messing up their schedule to college all when it turns out they weren't ready to do a startup yet'

@chrisc it must be a hell of a tough decision, I wonder what YC's metric for figuring out if a high school student is ready for startup life is? For me, YC comes at quite a good time, high school ends in early june just after the start of YC so the adjustment should be slightly easier
I'm a freshman at Acalanes High School who applied.

I pretty much dropped out of uni already. In my last test i just wrote a 3 page essay on why i don't care about economics. Probably the final nail in the coffin. If i don't get in, im gonna take my next student loan payment and just bootstrap

@devankoshal Im in almost the same boat as you, if we dont get into YC we're going to set up shop in London. We've already built up a pretty good network there, we managed to get a meeting with Steven Fry a couple of weeks ago to chat about what we're building. Things like that are such a good reminder of why startups are awesome.
You can always go back in to education, don't forget that.
Sweet, It would be pretty cool if we all got in.
@pg Interesting but what do you mean by mess up people's lives?
But saying all that, I started coding at 10/11 so I may have been in a better situation when I was 16, I don't know.
Anyone from east bay here?
@dami thanks

@LordJawsh Then maybe that would be OK. I'd have to look out for it on a case-by-case basis. I guess for a college dropout I'd almost assume they'd be OK, whereas a high schooler my default assumption would be the reverse, but I'd consider evidence to the contrary.
@jantire how old are you?
@Jantire Wow! High school freshman? Props to you buddy.
If I didn't leave school at 16 I guess I would still be in high school (18)

If I were deciding to fund high schoolers, what I'd be worried about is cost of failure. A Stanford dropout whose startup fails will have tons of job opportunities and their life will bounce back probably immediately. A high school dropout whose startup fails might be in a lot more trouble. I might be speaking out of ignorance though.

@simonify I could go back afterwards if I were to drop out but I would be in a much worse position than I started, I'd be graduating from college at least 1-2 years later than everyone else, and I know my parents would do everything they could to prevent me from dropping out, and the main reason for me to go to college is the social experience, and even more specific is to find good people I would want to work with for most of my life
@simonify but I don't want to drop out of school unless this gets far, schools my "backup plan" and I don't want to be forced into working at McDonalds or something if this doesn't work out

@simonify I'm going to stay in school unless this can make enough for financial independence for 3-5+ years, at the end of which if the startup is still growing then I would continue, but if not then college would be a good thing for me
@mlinsey just out of curiosity, what would you class as a good job opportunity?

I left at 16 as I got a job at a startup in Coventry. Quit a year later and have been wokring on my own projects since. I strongly believe real experience in the industry is more valuable than what you can learn in a classroom.
But if you feel that schools the best option then that's fine.
@simonify I agree real experience is a very good thing, but school teaches a widespread education, and I would like to have a college experience

@milinsey That's the reason why I'm not expecting to get in, I have the passion and ability to start a startup (or at least I believe I do), but although I know some coding and some deisgning, it's not enough to get a decent paying job at a startup
I'm getting good at Silverlight/.NET though, and I really like Visual Studio/Expression Blend
Each to their own :)

That's fair enough @jantire, but all I know is I've had the most amazing two years of my life since leaving school at 16, have made some amazing contacts, travelled the world on business and am in a great position to now get my startup off the ground.
I'd taken a Python class at College for Kids a few years ago but got the flu midway through and couldn't go to in the middle of it, and that kind of messed up the rest of it because I was so behind
@mlinsey but what if the high school dropout had job opportunities?
I started really coding last year, but even that wasn't really coding
but last summer I sat in at a class in UCDavis for 6 weeks that was an introductory computer science class (ECS30) and I learned a some C but I'm not good at it yet
@simonify Your lucky, I don't want to risk living with nothing until I have a viable backup plan
@LordJawsh I worry people's intellectual growth could be stunted by becoming a load-bearing structure too early.
It's not really luck, just having the guts to risk a few years.
@pg fair comment, how do you determine if a young founder is ready to become a load-bearing structure? Is there a specific criteria you work from?
@pg but what if most of our learning is being done outside of school? (Although I do think a generalized education is something worthwhile)
Finished high school, canceled palns for college to do a startup (and yes I applied)
follow me on github. https://github.com/joelbm24
